Utterance: Hi! Welcome back. How has your week been since we last spoke?
Hi, Ellie! It’s been a bit hectic, but I managed to have that conversation with my wife.
That’s great news! How did it go?
It went better than I expected. She was supportive and understood where I was coming from.
That’s wonderful to hear! What did you discuss specifically about your goals and the online courses?
I explained my desire to improve my skills and how that would help our family. She even encouraged me to sign up for a class.
That’s fantastic! Have you taken any steps toward enrolling in a course yet?
Yes, I signed up for one on coding. I’m really excited about it!
That’s a significant step forward. How does it feel to have made that commitment?
It feels empowering. I’m finally taking action instead of just thinking about it.
That’s a great mindset to have! Have you started any assignments or projects yet?
I just started the introductory module. It’s challenging, but I’m enjoying it so far.
That’s a positive sign! How do you feel about balancing your studies with family time?
I’ve been sticking to my plan of studying in the evenings, and it seems to be working out.
That’s excellent! Have you noticed any changes in your mood or stress levels since starting the course?
I feel more motivated and less stressed. It’s nice to have something for myself.
That’s wonderful! It seems like you’re finding a good balance. How has your daughter been adjusting to your study time?
She’s been okay with it. I make sure to spend quality time with her during the day.
That’s a great approach. What activities have you been doing together?
We’ve been going to the park more often, and I try to involve her in simple things at home, like cooking.
That sounds lovely! Involving her in activities can create great bonding moments. How does she respond to that?
She loves it! She gets so excited when she feels included.
That’s heartwarming to hear. It sounds like you’re nurturing a strong relationship with her. Are there any challenges you’re facing currently?
Sometimes I struggle with guilt when I’m studying and not spending time with her.
That’s a common feeling. Have you thought about how you could manage that guilt?
I try to remind myself that I’m doing this for her future, but it’s still hard.
It’s understandable. Perhaps setting specific times for family activities could help you feel more at ease when studying.
That’s a good idea. If I have planned family time, I can focus on my studies without feeling guilty.
Exactly! Creating that structure can help alleviate some of the guilt. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I’ve been thinking about my relationship with my parents again. I still feel a bit disconnected.
That’s an important topic. What specifically has been on your mind regarding your family?
I just wish I had a better relationship with them, but it feels like there’s a barrier.
It can be tough when family dynamics are strained. Have you considered reaching out to them?
I thought about it, but I’m not sure how they would respond.
It’s understandable to feel uncertain. What would be your goal in reaching out?
I’d like to reconnect and maybe understand why things are the way they are.
That’s a meaningful goal. How do you think you could initiate that conversation?
I could start with a simple text or call, just to check in and see how they’re doing.
That’s a great starting point. It opens the door for communication without too much pressure.
Yeah, I think I’ll try that.
I’m glad to hear that! We can follow up on how that goes in our next session.
Sounds good. Thanks for the encouragement, Ellie.
You’re doing great! I look forward to hearing about your progress next time.
Bye!
Goodbye!
